Yes lots. The language is basically the same. It has changed but all living Languages do. There was never a break where ancient Greek ended and modern Greek started unlike say French from Latin. Greeks are genetically related to their ancesters. Studies of skeletons show modern Greeks are of the same phynotype as ancients, a mix of alpine and Mediterranean peoples. Genetic studies have backed that up. Even minor DNA is still close to that of the modern people of Crete. Greece has had invasions but they never De-Hellenized Greece or replaced the people. Mostly they just added a bit. Greek DNA is still found in western Turks and Southern Italians who are decended from Greeks assimilated to those cultures. Some Greek food staples like bread, wine, olive oil (the Mediterranean trio) some cheese and folk dishes go back to antiquity. Others date from the Hellenistic, Roman and Byzantine periods when Greece was the center of trade. Even dishes with Turkish names (today) often predate Ottoman times. As for religion some Greeks have gone back to their native gods (as I have) paganism remained in parts of Greece after the year 800ce. Greek philosophy shaped Christianity. Practices, festivals, customs and beliefs survived in the church. Elements of Christianity show influence from Dionysus and Asklipios. Byzantine art drew on older styles. God's were recast as saints. Zeus was called the alpha and omega 1000 years before Christ. In Greek folk belief there are still gorgans and nymphs (often called nerida) fear of the unquiet dead and not letting the hearth fire go out existed into the 20th century.  Expressions like the god is raining, or the god is shaking his hair (for earthquakes) were common. Even greek urban legands, like the solider from the resistance killed in the civil war who comes back to seduce beautiful maidens or widows to impregnate them and raise any Army of sons to avenge his death draw on ancient themes. So yes, there is a relationship between modern Greece and ancient.

This is a question that has been over-done to be honest. However, let me entertain it again. Societies at large always change and evolve, and in this globalised age this effect has become dramatically more obvious. Through that all, it is undeniable that Modern Greeks are related in many ways to the Ancient Greeks, but are not in any case ‘the exact same people’. Not even the Ancient Greeks themselves were the exact same people - in fact, NO nation has ever been made by the exact same people. It’s just not possible. To explain how Greeks are related to Classical Greeks, we need to use a criterium. And so I say, who better than Herodotus? He uses this formula: τὸ Ἑλληνικόν, ἐὸν ὅμαιμόν τε καὶ ὁμόγλωσσον, καὶ θεῶν ἱδρύματά τε κοινὰ καὶ θυσίαι ἤθεά τε ὁμότροπα… The Hellenic nation, which is described by the same blood, same language, and common religious institutions, sacrifices and mannerisms… There are hence, broadly three criteria. Obviously, Herodotus used this specifically for the contemporary period, so below the criteria are used in a different, much wider sence - time:  Blood.Now, I have to say that to me blood is the least important of the three, but genetics do of course play their role in a nation. This being so, ‘purity of blood’ does not exist anywhere on the planet - we’re not immovable items, many people move around in search of new experiences, and this has perhaps applied no more to one people than the Greeks. Nonetheless, genetic evidence certainly shows that Modern Greeks descend, but not without foreign input, from the Minoans and Mycenaeans. This is described in this scientific study - Genetic origins of the Minoans and Mycenaeans [summarised here - The Greeks really do have near-mythical origins, ancient DNA reveals] Modern Greeks resemble the Mycenaeans, but with some additional dilution of the Early Neolithic ancestry. Our results support the idea of continuity but not isolation in the history of populations of the Aegean, before and after the time of its earliest civilizations. There’s also another way to see this - namely compare with neighbouring nations:   [SOURCE: http://www.uwyo.edu/buerkle/evol_life3500/papers/novembre08.pdf Genes mirror geography within Europe] As you see in the graph above, Greeks generally sit right in between the (mainly Southern) Italians, (Southern) Albanians and (Western) Turks, while being distant from the Slavic nations. All three of these share similarities in haplo-groups, as all three are majorly descendants of ancient people inhabiting that part of the Mediterranean. As such, in the weak criterium of genetics, the Greeks do certainly show strong affinity with the Ancient Greeks.  2. Language. This is a much better criterium. Now, as above, all aspects relating to humans advance, and this includes language. I do not think I have to say much here, insofar as Modern Greek is clearly a language that descends from Ancient Greek. Indeed, this is the line of progression:  [SOURCE: Indo-European Languages] Greek has among the longest recorded continuous use, and has progressed mostly naturally ever since. It is not easy for a Modern Greek speaker to read Attic Greek (unlike Koine Greek and later), but the language is still much closer to it than, say, English is to Old English - despite the former two differing by some 2500 years, and the latter by 1000 years. Hence, the language clearly comes from Classical Greek, following a very long progression path.  3. Culture (including religion) This is inevitably the trickiest part, by far. Like language, it is extremely important. Obviously, we’re talking about 2500 years here. In Europe, and in most of the world, we’re barely alike to our ancestors some 100 years ago, so imagine that times 25! The biggest difference here is, of course, religion. The Ancient Greeks believed in the ‘Dodecatheon’ (called ‘Hellenism’ outside Greece), a religion all too similar to most people. Modern Greeks are overwhelmingly Orthodox Christians, a religion that has been at odds with the former. This being noted, we must remember that it was the Ancient Greeks, whether by choice or force, that converted to Christianity - it’s not the case that (Modern) Greeks suddenly chose some 100, 500, 1000 etc years ago to switch religions. Ever since the Ancient Greeks converted, Christianity has been the dominant religion for the Greeks, and indeed said Greeks played an enormous role in its development, most notably the New Testament being written in Greek and (among others) addressed to Greek audiences, as well as the Great Schism of 1054 AD. What is clear all throughout, however, is that the Greek identity continued strong, even if the Greeks may have also used different umbrella terms throughout their history. Indeed, as a sample: Homer (born between 1200–800 BCE) - ‘οἵ τ' εἶχον Φθίην ἠδ' Ἑλλάδα καλλιγύναικα, Μυρμιδόνες δὲ καλεῦντο καὶ Ἕλληνες καὶ Ἀχαιοί’Isokrates (436–338 BCE) - ‘καὶ τὸ τῶν Ἑλλήνων ὄνομα πεποίηκε μηκέτι τοῦ γένους ἀλλὰ τῆς διανοίας δοκεῖν εἶναι, καὶ μᾶλλον Ἕλληνας καλεῖσθαι τοὺς τῆς παιδεύσεως τῆς ἡμετέρας ἢ τοὺς τῆς κοινῆς φύσεως μετέχοντας’Plutarch (45–127 AD) - τῶν ὅπλων ποιούντων λαμπρὸν οἱ μὲν Ἕλληνες ἔχαιρον ὁρῶντεςPalladas (300–400 AD) - ‘Ἄρα μὴ θανόντες τῷ δοκεῖν ζῶμεν μόνον, Ἕλληνες ἄνδρες, συμφορᾷ πεπτωκότες ὄνειρον εἰκάζοντες εἶναι τὸν βίον; ἢ ζῶμεν ἡμεῖς, τοῦ βίου τεθνηκότος;’Anna Komnene (1083–1153 AD) - ‘τὰ τῶν Ἑλλήνων συγγράμματα μεταχειριζόμενον καὶ τὸν ἀγράμματον Ἕλληνα ὀρθῶς ἑλληνίζοντα.’George Gemistos Plethon (1355-1452) - ‘Ἐσμὲν γὰρ οὗν ὧν ἡγεῖσθε τε καὶ βασιλεύετε ἕλληνες τὸ γένος ὡς ἥ τε φωνὴ καὶ ἡ πάτριος παιδεία μαρτυρεῖ’Αdamantios Korais (1748–1833) - ‘Δοῦλοι νὰ 'μεθα ὣς πότε, τῶν ἀχρείων Μουσουλμάνων, Τῆς Ἑλλάδος τῶν τυράννων;Outside these, culture is impossible to compare - we are, once again, talking of a difference of 2500 years! I can say for sure, though, that the basis of the Greek diet remains constant, namely olive oil, grapes et al.  In any case, everything is ultimately an opinion and you should form your own. I sure have formed mine :)

This is not an easy question and there is not an easy answer. Through out their written history, Greeks had some things in common. 1)They traveled a lot thus establishing trade routes and made colonies in various areas all around the Mediterranean sea. 2) Their main core was modern Greece and Ionia. 3) Due to economic and cultural reasons they embodied different populations in a similar way that the Roman did later in their history. Before Alexander the Great, Greek and Greek-speaking populations were mainly in the Balkans, Asia minor, Black sea, South Italy, South France (Massilia) and smaller trade cities all around the Mediterranean. After Alexander’s conquest and the 2 centuries of “Diadochi”, Greeks (influence, culture, mixed paganistic religion and language, Koine) spread all over Egypt, Judea, Syria and Asia as far as India (Greco-Buddhism) creating Hellenistic kingdoms. "Hellenistic" is distinguished from "Hellenic" in that the first encompasses the entire sphere of direct ancient Greek influence, while the latter refers to Greece itself. In these areas they mixed with local population creating Hellenized cultures that would be dominant through the Roman reign and later the Byzantine (Eastern Roman Empire). Roman-Latin culture was not strong enough to eliminate the Greek language, like it did in Spain, France etc.This weakness on behalf of the Romans allowed the Greek speaking part of the empire to survive the fall of Rome and struggle it’s way until 1453. The people of Romania(Byzantium) considered themselves Romans although Greek was the official language. The population under Costantinople’s reign was a mixtue of Greeks, Slavs, Armenians, Latins and various Estern populations. The name Greek was used to describe the pagan, the non-christian and Western Europe used it as a term to insult or categorize the so-called Romans of the East. If it wasn’t for the language, we could not speak about modern day Greeks, that is a fact. It was only after Romania (Byzantium) had lost huge amounts of territory, under the threat of the Ottomans and the West was considered more or less an enemy that the Greeks of Byzantium started calling themselves Greeks again. Let’s not forget that the term “nation” was not what it is today. Religion, areas of influence and wealth were more likely to determine your identity than the place of your birth. Many Roman emperors were from Serbia, North Africa etc. It is safe to assume that Greeks donated DNA with their presence in all the places they have been influential same as the Romans. Some places maintained dominant Greeks until the Middle ages such as the Balkan peninsula, South Italy, Sicily (until the 10th century), Egypt, Judea, Syria (until the apperance of Islam) and Asia minor. It is unsafe to imagine the percentage of this spread due to war, slave trade and the moving of different groups.The main difference between Romans and Greeks in terms of survival is that the Greeks adjusted and continued. Plus they handled enemies better using not only war but bribe and diplomacy (ex. Sicilian Vesper). When under Rome they became Romans, when under Roman Eastern Empire they became Christians and spread Orthodox Christinity to the slavic nations (Bulgaria, Russia, Serbia etc). In Italy, barbaric invaders like the Goths and the Lombards eventually settled in the conquered territories, mixed with them and later created something new. In Greece the Slavic invaders only settled for a while and the Turks later mostly took Greek children and wives but rarely the opposite. The Romans took Greek elements thus left the Greeks with their culture that eventually turned them to the high power status of Byzantium. Same cannot be said for the Ottomans. Religion was far too important at the time to allow a mixture. Up until 1821 and the war of independence Greeks were part of an Islamic empire. To conclude we could say that the Greeks came to mix with every culture that was part of the Mediterranean sea while maintaining today Greece and Ionia as the core. Romans, Persians, Slavs, Armenians, Venetians, Franks, Albanians and Turks are part of today’s Greek population but due to geography and culture we can always assume that today’s Greeks have serious connections with their ancient forefathers.
